awd_titl_txt: NRT-IGE: Fostering Effective Oral Communication Skills for STEM Graduate Students
awd_abstract_narration:
Graduate education in the sciences, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) rigorously prepares students to innovate in their fields, yet it often does not include formal training in how to effectively communicate those innovations to others. To ensure we live in a just and vibrant society, it is vital that scientists are able to share their research findings with scientists in other fields, non-science experts, and the public.  Using knowledge from the performing arts, this project will implement a novel pilot training program to teach oral communication to STEM graduate students, facilitating a deeper understanding of communication and providing practice in public speaking, improvisational techniques, and reading body language. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) track to Montana State University-Bozeman will modernize STEM graduate education by pinpointing aspects of oral communication training that positively impact students' abilities to communicate orally to a wide variety of audiences, and increase the public's understanding of and engagement with science. Three recruited cohorts of eight STEM graduate students will practice and refine their oral communication skills by creating podcasts and speaking at community events in which they explain their research to the public. The team working on this project includes domain experts in physics, biology, mathematics, and engineering, as well as experts in public speaking, acting, education research, and library sciences. This broad expertise will ensure that disciplinarily diverse STEM students are recruited into the program, providing interdisciplinary perspectives and instruction and facilitating the success of this pilot graduate training program. 

This research will investigate whether targeted intervention in oral communication skills for STEM graduate students improves their ability to effectively convey their research to a broad audience. The project will use formative, summative, and longitudinal assessments to determine how various portions of the intervention are successful in developing students' oral communication skills in the following realms: avoiding the use of jargon, public speaking skills, and non-verbal delivery skills. Assessment data for year-long longitudinal studies of each cohort will include survey data related to three areas of oral communication, self-reports from students, and interviews with students and their mentors. To assess competencies such as reducing jargon for communicating with the public, this project will create, modify and use rubrics for effective public speaking. Pre- and post-intervention data will be compared among students and cohorts to determine the effects of each aspect of the training. Results and successes will be shared nationwide with other STEM experts at domain-specific conferences as well as at American Association for the Advancement of Sciences National Conferences. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the NSF IGE STEM Storytellers project were twofold. First, the research team developed a year-long curriculum to teach oral communication skills to STEM graduate students. Using a framework of connect, convey, and captivate, students learned how to discuss their thesis work with non-experts. The students in the program practiced improvisation, with a strong emphasis on developing careful and attentive listening skills and interacting positively with others. Students also created and edited a number of podcasts, which can be heard on Anchor.  Learning how to critique each other was an important part of the course. Students also spent time developing and honing analogies to effectively convey information about their thesis work. Finally, students gave public talks about their research, some of which can be found on YouTube. During practice talks given to an audience of freshman, students practiced effectively answering questions, and paying attention to a live audience.  Over the academic year, students kept reflective journals, in which they detailed their thoughts, experiences, and notes from peer critiques of their podcasts and practice talks.

The second goal of the program was to adapt and develop assessment tools for oral communication. These assessment tools included determining how much jargon students used before and after the year long class, an expansion of the Public Speaking Competency rubric (by Schreiber et al.), a short anxiety survey by Marteau, and a survey measuring communication apprehension by McCroskey.  

The research team developed an open-source R script that will estimate the amount of jargon in any piece of written work.  Words that are likely jargon are displayed in a list, and word clouds can be created that graphically display which words are used the most in any written piece. This script was applied to all three student cohorts in the program, and students overall used less jargon after completing the course compared to before the course began. This script is freely available on our website. An article has been published about this script, and can be found here: https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0963662520937436  

Further, the research team expanded the Public Speaking Competency Rubric to include a set of rubric items to measure non-verbal aspects of communication. This rubric can be used for both formative and summative assessment of students? oral communication skills. The expanded rubric also has the benefit of being a complete tool for providing student feedback. Once filled out, the rubric can be used as feedback when given to students without additional materials. A manuscript about this expansion is currently under review.

Another assessment tool used by the research team was a six item anxiety measure. Students periodically completed this survey during the academic year. Students also took a survey before and after the course which measured their communication apprehension in a variety of contexts.  Finally, an in-house public survey was created so public audiences could assess the extent to which students were connecting with the audience, effectively conveying information, and captivating the audience during the publicly given talks. There was a strong correlation between the research team?s assessment of student talks using the competency rubric and the public 3C survey results.

In sum, we have developed a full curriculum to teach and assess oral communication to STEM graduate students.  The curricular materials, assessment tools, recorded talks, and podcasts can all be found on our website:  www.montana.edu/stemstorytellers
